citations.narrative:
The night house dens for five (5) white-throated capuchins, a black howler monkey and a red-ruffed lemur have excessive
rust. The black howler and white-throated capuchins had excessive rust on their perches and along the bottom edges of
their enclosure. The red-ruffed lemur had excessive rust along the bottom edges of it's enclosure.
Rusty surfaces cannot be effectively cleaned and sanitized. Any surfaces that come in contact with nonhuman primates
must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that affects the structural strength of
the surface.
Correct by 1 November 2025

The primary shelter housing two (2) ring tailed lemurs has a perimeter fence that is 6 feet tall but not at least 3 feet away
from the primary enclosure. On the entire length of the back side of the enclosure, where the perimeter fence parallels the
rear wall, there is less than a foot between the two structures.
The lack of a sufficient distance between the perimeter fence and their primary enclosure presents a safety risk to the
animals. The facility must ensure that the outdoor area of their sheltered nonhuman primate housing is enclosed by an
adequate perimeter fence, 6-feet tall, that is constructed so that it restricts unauthorized humans, and animals the size of
dogs, skunks, and raccoons from going through it or under it and having contact with the nonhuman primates. The
perimeter fence must be effective, continuous, and at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure.
Correct by 31 December 2025

The primary shelter housing two (2) caracals has a perimeter fence that is 6 feet tall but not at least 3 feet away from the
primary enclosure. On the entire length of the back side of the enclosure, where the perimeter fence parallels the rear
wall, there is less than a foot between the two structures.
It's important to maintain at least 3 feet between the enclosure and the perimeter fence to ensure that the regulated
animals are protected from unauthorized persons and animals which may intend to have contact with them from outside
the fence.
The perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact
between animals inside the enclosures and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less that 3 feet
in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator.
Correct by 31 December 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
n

narrative:
3.75(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The night house dens for five (5) white-throated capuchins, a black howler monkey and a red-ruffed lemur have excessive 
rust. The black howler and white-throated capuchins had excessive rust on their perches and along the bottom edges of 
their enclosure. The red-ruffed lemur had excessive rust along the bottom edges of it's enclosure.  
Rusty surfaces cannot be effectively cleaned and sanitized. Any surfaces that come in contact with nonhuman primates 
must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that affects the structural strength of 
the surface. 
 
Correct by 1 November 2025 
3.77(f) 
   
Sheltered housing facilities. 
The primary shelter housing two (2) ring tailed lemurs has a perimeter fence that is 6 feet tall but not at least 3 feet away 
from the primary enclosure. On the entire length of the back side of the enclosure, where the perimeter fence parallels the 
rear wall, there is less than a foot between the two structures.  
The lack of a sufficient distance between the perimeter fence and their primary enclosure presents a safety risk to the 
animals. The facility must ensure that the outdoor area of their sheltered nonhuman primate housing is enclosed by an 
adequate perimeter fence, 6-feet tall, that is constructed so that it restricts unauthorized humans, and animals the size of 
dogs, skunks, and raccoons from going through it or under it and having contact with the nonhuman primates. The 
perimeter fence must be effective, continuous, and at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure. 
 
Correct by 31 December 2025 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The primary shelter housing two (2) caracals has a perimeter fence that is 6 feet tall but not at least 3 feet away from the 
primary enclosure. On the entire length of the back side of the enclosure, where the perimeter fence parallels the rear 
wall, there is less than a foot between the two structures.

It's important to maintain at least 3 feet between the enclosure and the perimeter fence to ensure that the regulated 
animals are protected from unauthorized persons and animals which may intend to have contact with them from outside 
the fence. 
 
The perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact 
between animals inside the enclosures and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less that 3 feet 
in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator. 
 
Correct by 31 December 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative. 
 
 n
